item.title: PCA Analysis of Climate Variables
item.description:
Introduction

Environmental and climatic factors of 243 countries were compiled by @zander_venter on Kaggle through Google Earth and public remote sensing data. This analysis looks to examine the multivariate relationship between climatological and land use factors inlcuding accessibility to cities, elevation, cropland cover, tree canopy cover, mean temperature, mean rainfall, and cloudiness for countries listed as having greater than 50% cropland cover. In the following principle components analysis, the relationshiop between these factors and their correlation is explored (Figure 1).

Necessary packages for this analysis include: tidyverse, janitor, and ggfortify. All data analysis and visualization was produced using RStudio Version 1.2.1335

PCA Analysis

# Read in data

variables <- read_csv("world_env_vars.csv") %>% 
  clean_names() 

# Wrangle data to filter countries with greater than 50.0 cropland_cover metrics
# Select climate related variables as well as land use variables including accessibility_to_cities, elevation, cropland_cover, tree_canopy_cover, temp_mean_annual, rain_mean_annual, and cloudiness
# Remove observations, if any, that have 'na' values for any variable(s)

variables_sub <- variables %>% 
  filter(cropland_cover > 50.0) %>% 
  select(accessibility_to_cities, elevation, cropland_cover, tree_canopy_cover, temp_mean_annual, rain_mean_annual, cloudiness) %>% 
  drop_na()

# Create primary components analysis 

my_pca <- prcomp(variables_sub, scale = TRUE)

# View PCA
#my_pca      #(uncheck to see compenenet eigenvalues/eigenvectors)

# Create biplot using PCA created above

my_biplot <- autoplot(my_pca,
                      colour = NA, 
                      loadings.label = TRUE,
                      loadings.label.size = 3,
                      loadings.label.colour = "black",
                      loadings.label.repel = TRUE) +
  theme_bw() +
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(-.35, 0.3)) +
  scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0, 0)) +
  labs(title = "Principle components analysis plot of climate and land-use variables",
       x = "Principle Component 1 (34.48%)",
       y = "Principle Component 2 (26.69%)")

# View biplot
my_biplot

Figure 1. Principle components analysis for accessibility to cities, elevation, cropland cover, tree canopy cover, mean temperature, mean rainfall, and cloudiness for countries with greater than 50% cropland cover. Data from: Zander Venter

Summary

  • Tree canopy cover and cropland cover values are inverseley related
    • This makes sense, as cropland and forested areas are drastically different land uses
  • Tree cover and cropland cover show minimal correlation to average rainfall and average temperature
  • Elevation and cropland cover are negatively correlated
    • Possibly do to less suitable cropland at high elevations
  • Elevation and accessibility to cities are positively correlated
  • Cloudiness and tree canopy cover are positively correlated, possibly due to increased evapotranspiration.

item.title: Snowshoe Hare Abundance Analysis
item.description:
Introduction

The following analysis looks at the abundance and body weight statistics of snowshoe hare populations sampled by the Bonanza Creek Long-Term Ecological Research team in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest outside of Fairbanks, Alaska. Snowshoe hare weight by species sex was then compared and plotted (Figure 3). Summary statistics, including mean weight in grams, standard deviation, standard error, and sample size are provided for males and females (Table 1).

Necessary packages for this analysis include: tidyverse, janitor, kableExtra, and ggbeeswarm. All data analysis and visualization was produced using RStudio Version 1.2.1335.

Figure 1. Snowshoe Hare (Lepus americanus). Credit: The National Wildlife Federation

Figure 2. Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest map. Credit: PolarTec

Analysis

# Read in data:

snowshoes <- read_csv("showshoe_lter.csv")


# Wrangle data to select for sex, weight, and grid
# Tidy data to lowercase format, filtered for only confirmed males and females (omitted any data entries with ?)
# dropped all observations with 'na'
snowshoes_tidy2 <- snowshoes %>% 
  select(sex, weight, grid) %>% 
  mutate(grid = str_to_lower(grid)) %>% 
  mutate(sex = str_to_lower(sex)) %>% 
  filter(sex %in% c("m", "f")) %>% 
  mutate(sex = case_when(
    sex == "m" ~ "Male",
    sex == "f" ~ "Female"
  )) %>% 
  drop_na()
# Visualize data in beeswarm
# facet by sampling grid and separate by sex

ggplot(data = snowshoes_tidy2, aes(x = sex, y = weight)) +
  geom_beeswarm(aes(color = sex), size = 0.5, width = 0.2, show.legend = FALSE) +
  theme_bw() +
  facet_wrap(~grid) +
  labs(title = "Snowshoe Hare weight by sex for each sampling grid",
       subtitle = "1998 - 2012",
       x = "Sex",
       y = "Weight (g)")

Figure 3. Beeswarm plot showing weights of individual Snowshoe Hares across three sampling plots. Females are represented by the orange points, and Males are represented by the blue points. There is no clear visual difference in weight between males and females. Bonbs site refers to a site used to live trap hares. Bonmat refers to “Bonanza Mature” - a mature forest sampling site for hares. Bonrip refers to “Bonanza Riparian” - a flood zone and forested area sampling site. Abundance of hares in bonrip and bonbs greatly outnumberd abundance in bonmat. Data: Bonanza Creek Long-Term Ecological Research

Summary Statistics

Table 1. The table below shows summary statistics for Snowshoe Hare weight by sex, including mean weight in grams, standard deviation, standard error, and sample size. Female Hares have a slightly larger mean weight than males across all sites. Data: Bonanza Creek Long-Term Ecological Research

# Summary statistics

snowshoes_summary <- snowshoes_tidy2 %>%
  group_by(sex) %>% 
  summarize(mean_weight = mean(weight),
            sd_weight = sd(weight),
            standard_error = (sd(weight)/sqrt(length(weight))),
            sample_size = n()) %>% 
  mutate_if(is.numeric, round, 2)

snowshoes_summary %>% 
  kable(col.names = c("Sex", "Mean Weight (g)", "Standard Deviation", "Standard Error", "Sample Size")) %>% 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped", full_width = F, position = "left") %>% 
  add_header_above(c("Snowshoe hare summary statistics by sex" = 5))
Snowshoe hare summary statistics by sex
Sex Mean Weight (g) Standard Deviation Standard Error Sample Size
Female 1365.16 347.45 8.94 1511
Male 1349.94 305.73 9.15 1117

Referances

Kielland K., F. S. Chapin, R. W. Ruess. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14

item.title: Steelhead Migration Time Series Analysis
item.description:
Introduction

Steelhead passage through the Bonneville Dam in Oregon has been recorded on a daily basis from 1939 through September of 2019, and the data for these recordings has been provided by Columbia Basin Research at the University of Washington. This report explores time series data and visualizes daily, monthly, and annual counts of steelhead passage through the dam from 1939 to 2019 (Figures 2, 3, 4). These visualizations show temporal variation in steelhead passage through the years.

RStudio packages for this analysis include: tidyverse, janitor, lubridate, here, tsibble, and paletteer. All data analysis and visualization was produced using RStudio Version 1.2.1335.

Figure 1. Bonneville Dam, Oregon. Credit: US Army Corps of Engineers

# Read in and look at data

fish <- read_csv("cbr_fish_passage_bonneville_allyrs_steelhead.csv") %>% 
  mutate(location = str_to_lower(location), parameter = str_to_lower(parameter)) %>% 
  rename("mmdd" = "mm-dd")

# names(fish)
# unique(fish$parameter)
# unique(fish$`mm-dd`)
# unique(fish$unit)
# unique(fish$datatype)
# unique(fish$value)
# Parse dates

fish_clean <- fish %>% 
  mutate(yearmonthday = str_c(year, mmdd, sep = "-")) %>% 
  mutate(year_mo_day = lubridate::parse_date_time(yearmonthday, "ydm")) %>% 
  mutate(day = day(year_mo_day)) %>% 
  mutate(month = month(year_mo_day, label = TRUE)) %>% 
  drop_na(value)
  

fish_dates <- fish %>% 
  mutate(mo_day = lubridate::parse_date_time(mmdd, "dm")) %>% 
  mutate(day = day(mo_day)) %>% 
  mutate(month = month(mo_day, label = TRUE)) %>% 
  select(-mo_day) 
# Plot time series of daily data
# fish_ts <- as_tsibble(fish_clean, key = value, index = month)

Daily variation in steelhead passage:

# daily plot through the years

ggplot(data = fish_clean, aes(x = year_mo_day, y = value)) +
  geom_line(color = "blue", size = 0.2) +
  labs(x = "year",
       y = "steelhead passing per day",
       title = "Daily steelhead passage through Bonneville Damn",
       subtitle = "1939-2019") +
  theme_dark() +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0,35000))

Figure 2. Daily observations for counts of steelhead passing through Bonneville Dam visualized. Daily counts appear to follow a consistant seasonality with the start of each year experiencing much lower counts than the middle of each year. Daily counts peak in 2009 and taper off to lower than 1940 daily values at the end of 2019. Data: Columbia Basin Research

Monthly variation in steelhead passage:

# Monthly passage through the years

fish_monthly <- fish_clean %>% 
  mutate(month_sep = yearmonth(year_mo_day)) %>% 
  group_by(month_sep, year, month) %>% 
  tally(value)

ggplot(data = fish_monthly, aes(x = year, y = n)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = month), show.legend = TRUE) +
  theme_dark() +
  scale_y_discrete(limits = c(0, 50000, 100000, 150000, 200000, 250000, 300000, 350000)) +
  scale_x_discrete(limits = c(1940, 1960, 1980, 2000, 2020)) +
  scale_color_paletteer_d("palettetown::rayquaza") +
  labs(x = "year",
       y = "monthly count",
       title = "Monthly steelhead counts through Bonneville Dam",
       subtitle = "1939-2019")

Figure 3. Monthly observations for counts of steelhead passing through Bonneville Dam visualized. Counts of steelhead passing are aggreggated by month from 1939 to 2019. Here we see the highest counts through the years are observed in July (yellow), August (brown), and September (gold), with hardly any observations in the winter months. Data: Columbia Basin Research

Annual variation in steelhead passage:

# Annual passage of fish through Bonneville Dam
fish_annual <- fish_clean %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(tot = sum(value))

ggplot(data = fish_annual, aes(x = year, y = tot)) +
  geom_line(color = "purple") +
  theme_dark() +
  scale_y_discrete(limits = c(0, 100000, 200000, 300000, 400000, 500000, 600000, 6550000)) +
  scale_x_discrete(limits = c(1940, 1960, 1980, 2000, 2020)) +
  labs(x = "year",
       y = "annual count",
       title = "Annual steelhead counts through Bonneville Dam",
       subtitle = "1939-2019")

Figure 4. Annual counts of steelhead passing through Bonneville Dam visualized by the purple line from 1939 to 2019. Counts remain below 400,000 steelheads annually, with the first big peak reaching around 380,000 in 1986. The largest peaks occur in 2001 and 2009, with 633,073 and 604,970 steelheads, respectively. Since 2009, annual steelhead passage through the dam has decreased, to a low of 77,195 in 2019. Data: Columbia Basin Research

Sources: Columbia River DART, Columbia Basin Research, University of Washington. (2019). Adult Passage Graphics & Text. Available from http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_graph_text
